objinfo.objorder: 1-17Bentley designates the manuscript pages as pages 1-15. He does not include the blue-grey paper wrappers (objects 1 and 17 of this edition) that enclose the manuscript pages in his pagination.
objinfo.numberleaves: 10The manuscript consists of 8 leaves, in addition to 2 leaves of blue-grey paper (one placed at the beginning of the manuscript and the other at the end), acting as wrappers. Each leaf of the manuscript was originally half of a folio, as were the 2 leaves acting as wrappers. At some point in the manuscript's history, the folded pages and wrapper were cut with a knife, without the aid of a ruler, close to the stab holes. Some manuscript leaves (objects 3, 5, 7, 10, 13, and 14) are only partially filled with writing, creating blank spaces of varying size within the written text. (The final manuscript page, object 16, is also only partially filled, but this is to be expected.) Each gap corresponds with the end of a numbered section of the text. In Blake Books, Bentley overlooks the small gap at the bottom of object 5 (page 4 according to his pagination), and therefore concludes that such spaces only occur at the end of “most” sections (page 448).
objinfo.watermark: Britannia type watermark, undated, with crowned "G R" countermark.None of the leaves display the watermark in its entirety.
objinfo.pennednumbers: 1-8 on objects 2, 4, 6, 8, 11, 12, 14, and 15These numbers, which are centered at the top of the listed objects, correspond to sections of text and are not intended to serve as page or leaf numbers. In addition, each leaf (every other page) of the manuscript is paginated in pencil in the top right corner of the object, beginning with the number 2 on object 2 and ending with the number 9 on object 16. However, these penciled numbers are written in a hand other than Blake’s and are therefore not included in this transcription.
objinfo.binding: bound in blue moroccoThe present blue morocco binding was created after the Sotheby's sale of 1903, by either Bernard Quaritch or the British Library (then the British Museum). The leaves of the manuscript are enclosed in the above-mentioned wrappers and mounted on stubs.
objinfo.stabholes: 2 sets of 3 stab holes (6 holes total), top set approx. 5.0 cm. from top of leaf and second set approx. 5.0 cm. from first set The 4 original folios were stabbed through the wrapper, and the stab holes are located in the left margins of the rectos. In addition, the last 2 leaves each have an additional set of 5 stab holes in the bottom margin.

provenance.name: British Library
provenance.note: The early history of the manuscript is not known. At some point prior to 1874, it became the property of Anne Gilchrist. Lost for a time, the manuscript was later found in the office of George Bell and Son and was acquired by the dealer Bernard Quaritch at Sotheby's, 29 July 1903, lot 458 (£28). The manuscript was offered for sale by Quaritch in October, 1905 (catalogue no. 243, item 180) for £125 and again in January, 1909 (catalogue no. 271, item 194) for £50. It was purchased by the British Museum from Quaritch on 13 Feb. 1909 and is now housed in the British Library.

objnote.p: This object is one of 2 leaves of blue-grey paper (the other is object 17, placed at the end of the manuscript) acting as wrappers. These leaves were originally half of a folio, as were the leaves of the manuscript. At some point in the manuscript's history, the wrapper and folded pages were cut with a knife, without the aid of a ruler, close to the stab holes, which are located in the left margins of the rectos.

In his edition of Tiriel, Bentley notes that the inscription on this object "has been ascribed to Blake" and makes no further comment (page 52), while in Blake Books he states that the writing may be in Blake's hand (page 448). Erdman, who reads the inscription as "Tiriel / MS. by Mr Blake", states with certainty that the handwriting is Blake's (page 814n). However, Alexander Gourlay concludes, and the editors of the William Blake Archive agree, that while the word “Tiriel” is consistent with Blake’s formal copperplate hand, the rest of the inscription, written in a different ink (the title appears in a black ink or watercolor that produces a crisp line, while the second line of text is written in a brown ink that bleeds) and in a hand that does not resemble Blake’s, is a later annotation. He notes that “MS by Mr. Blake” appears to be in the hand of publisher J. Johnson, to whom Blake may have submitted the manuscript (e-mail correspondence of Gourlay and the editors, 22 March 2013).

Lines 9-14 are deleted with four vertical strokes. Additional strokes branch off of the bottom of the third, as if Blake attempted to make the original stroke darker by tracing over it more than once, but his pen diverged each time. l.note: Bentley reads the partially illegible word as "Clithyma(?)" (Tiriel, page 76; Writings volume 2, page 912), while Erdman reads "Clithyma" with certainty (page 814n). This name does not appear elsewhere in Tiriel and consists largely of unclear characters and overwritten text composed of pen strokes that do not vary in intensity (thereby making it difficult to distinguish between original characters and their emendations). The character(s) immediately following the "C" may be "h" or "li", in which there is no visible dot over the "i". The next character may be "l" or "t" (or a combination of the two, in which one serves as an emendation of the other). The fourth or fifth character (depending upon one's reading) could be "t", "n", "l", or "h". This unknown character is certainly an emendation, and the original character and its subsequent emendation(s) may involve any combination of the suggested letters. In lines 25 and 27, the name “Hela” is transcribed as being mended from “Hali”. Erdman suggests that the name was originally written as “Hili”, noting that "the first vowel is conjectural, but is not 'e'" (page 815n). Bentley claims that, in both cases, the "e" in "Hela" "is faulty, as if it were an 'a' which has been written over" (Tiriel, page 90n; Writings volume 2, page 914n).* However, he does not offer a reading of the final letter of the name, which is also mended. Presumably, Bentley reads the first version of the name as “Hala”.

“Hali” is the preferred reading here for several reasons. First of all, in both lines 25 and 27, the pen strokes constituting the second letter of the original name more closely resemble an “a” (outlined in red in the second image from line 27 below) than Erdman’s suggested “i”. (The "e" in "Hela" is outlined in red in the third image.)

Furthermore, there are no visible erasure marks above the letters in question. These would most likely be present had the second letter of the name once been “i”, indicating Blake’s attempt to obscure the dot above that letter. However, while there are no marks above the second letter of the name in either line 25 or line 27, there are smudges above the final letter of the name in both cases (see the image from line 25 below), indicating the erasure of the dot of an “i” and supporting Erdman’s assertion that the final letter of the name was originally “i”.
*Bentley mistakenly omits a reference to line 27 (line 268 in his text) in the note on page 90 of his edition of Tiriel.

objnote.p: Erdman states that, beginning with line 6 of object 15, "the rest of the ms is written with a different pen and in more hurried script" and asserts that "some time may have elapsed before Blake returned to finish the work" (page 815n). Bentley also notes that the final lines of Tiriel are written with "a sharper pen". However, he states that there is little evidence to suggest that they were written at a later date (Tiriel, page 90n; Writings volume 2, page 918n).

In The Book of Thel, the speech that Thel hears while standing at her own grave plot (Bentley plate 8) resembles Tiriel's final speech (beginning at line 8 of this object), not only in its use of rhetorical questions (a device often employed by Blake in his works from this period), but also in its imagery and themes.

objnote.p: This object is one of 2 leaves of blue-grey paper (the other is object 1, placed at the beginning of the manuscript) acting as wrappers. These leaves were originally half of a folio, as were the leaves of the manuscript. At some point in the manuscript's history, the wrapper and folded pages were cut with a knife, without the aid of a ruler, close to the stab holes, which are located in the left margins of the rectos.
